docs.lead_paragraph: The Class Act always flew a bit under the radar. It's a big idea -- the first voluntary public plan for long-term care insurance, a legacy of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy -- that was overshadowed by bitter debates over the rest of the health care legislation in which it was included.
docs.abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services is looking for caregivers, among others, to join a panel devising a strategy for implementing the Class Act, the first public plan for long-term care insurance.
docs.snippet: The Department of Health and Human Services is looking for caregivers, among others, to join a panel devising a strategy for implementing the Class Act, the first public plan for long-term care insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, regulators dealt with the crisis in Texas banking by letting financial institutions go bankrupt. That solution is unlikely to work in Ireland.

headline.main: The Texas Fix Is Unlikely for Ireland
headline.print_headline: The Texas Fix Is Unlikely For Ireland

docs.snippet: In the 1980s, regulators dealt with the crisis in Texas banking by letting financial institutions go bankrupt. That solution is unlikely to work in Ireland.

docs.lead_paragraph: Now is the time for bold attempts at bipartisan policymaking, apparently. In the wake of the Simpson-Bowles blueprint comes an even more detailed vision for deficit reduction from the Bipartisan Policy Center, which some of the liberal wonks who snarked at Simpson-Bowles have decided is a budget-balancing proposal they can get behind. (That's a good thing, to my mind, because the B.P.C. report and Simpson-Bowles are both much closer to one another than either is to the current left-wing vision of how to bring the budget into balance.) Meanwhile, Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan has persuaded Alice Rivlin, Bill Clinton's former O.M.B. director, to join him in championing a sweeping overhaul of Medicare, which would transform the program from an open-ended entitlement into a means-tested system that provides vouchers to purchase health insurance.
docs.abstract: Ron Wyden and Scott Brown have a plan.
docs.snippet: Ron Wyden and Scott Brown have a plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald M. Berwick, the new chief of the programs, told members of the Senate Finance Committee on Wednesday that the law protected Medicare benefits, and he denounced efforts to repeal it.
